Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Microscopic Deployment Algorithms to Achieve Macroscopic Objectives for Spatially Distributed Stochastic Networks of Mobile Agents

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will study new ways to control large networks of mobile agents to accomplish a variety of tasks. The first challenge addressed by this project is to account for uncertainty in the position and velocity of each agent. This uncertainty can be caused by inaccurate measurements or imperfect communications. To capture uncertainty, this project uses probability distributions to quantify the collective behavior of all the agents. This is called the macroscopic description of the network. The second challenge addressed by this project is to find control laws that achieve a desired macroscopic behavior of the network, using only distributed algorithms and local information. That is, the project will find rules by which each agent will control its own velocity, based only on knowledge of a few neighboring agents, but in such a way that a desired macroscopic probability distribution is obtained. The local dynamic behavior of the individual agents is called the microscopic description of the network, and the goal of this project is to find rules for microscopic behavior that give rise to a desired macroscopic result. An example is the control of a large group of autonomous mobile robots that pick up and deliver packages across a wide geographic region. The macroscopic goal is that, for each point in the region, the probability density of a delivery robot being available should match the probability density that a package needs to be picked up. For large numbers of robots, it is impractical to achieve this macroscopic goal by controlling every individual robot from a single command center. Instead, to avoid prohibitive requirements for communication bandwidth, information storage, and data processing, the computational task should be distributed among the individual robots -- however, the individual robots can only share data with a few nearby units. The challenge addressed by this project is for the individual robots to plan their movements based only on this limited local exchange, in such a way that the entire network of robots spreads out across the delivery region in a pattern mirroring the customer demand. This project advances the national prosperity and helps to secure the national defense by improving the ability to control large networks of mobile robots for commercial applications such as package delivery, or security applications such as surveillance and interdiction.

The macroscopic deployment problem is approached in three steps. The first step is to define a single fictitious agent that captures the macroscopic state of the multi-agent network. This is done by choosing the mean and the covariance of the individual states of all the constituent agents of the network to be the statistical quantities that determine the probability distribution of the state of the representative agent. Tools from stochastic optimal control theory are then applied to steer the network towards areas of high importance. The second step is to solve the microscopic deployment problem for the constituent agents of the network, by assigning tasks to different agents based on their suitability to accomplish these tasks. The proposed solution approach is based on a divide-and-conquer scheme that is centered around a special class of Voronoi-like spatial partitions (sub-divisions of the workspace of the multi-agent network). The expected outcomes of this effort will include 1) stochastic control algorithms for the solution of the macroscopic control problem, 2) partitioning algorithms for the computation of Voronoi-like subdivisions of the network's workspace, 3) distributed algorithms for the solution of the microscopic control problem that leverage the Voronoi-like partitions and Lloyd's algorithm. The third and final step is to validate the proposed algorithms via a set of experimental demonstrations that will take place at the facilities for robotics research at the PI's home department.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have created a suite of novel algorithms for optimal deployment of teams comprised of intelligent mobile agents (that is, drones, mobile ground robots, autonomous vehicles, etc.) which have been assigned to perform tasks at different locations over a large geographic region. The delivery of goods by a fleet of aerial or ground mobile robots and the use of interconnected teams of autonomous vehicles for emergency management and disaster response situations correspond to two characteristic examples of the envisioned applications of this research. In problems of this type, the constituents of the multi-agent team are required to allocate resources and distribute the workload among them in a fair and optimal way while accounting for the service demand (that is, where and when they are needed the most). Because the demand changes both temporally and spatially in general, the agents must continuously update their priorities and courses of action.

The key novel idea of this project lies in the two-level modelling of a multiagent network. At the high level, the network can be treated as a single unit, which is described in terms of its ?macroscopic state? (the latter state corresponds to, for instance, the density of the population of agents), whereas at the low level, it can be viewed as a collection of individuals each of which has its own ?microscopic? state (e.g., position or position and velocity). Based on this interpretation, we created new distributed control algorithms for deployment of multi-agent networks which ensure that the macroscopic state of the network adapts to the changes of the service demand whereas the agents of the network interact locally in such a way that their combined individual actions induce desired behaviors for the network at the macroscopic level. In our developed two-level approach, the decision-making / control problems at the low (microscopic) level and the high (macroscopic) level are inherently coupled with each other.

The main outcomes of this research effort include the creation of a general two-level (combined macroscopic and microscopic) framework for distributed coverage / deployment control of multiagent networks that allows the latter to adapt to changes of the service demand along with more specialized tools for the high-level and the low-level control problems separately. For the high-level control problem, we created distribution steering algorithms for uncertain nonlinear systems, that is, algorithms that can steer the probability distribution of the uncertain state of such systems to a goal distribution (macroscopic control based on global information). In particular, we have developed distribution steering algorithms based on both model-based and model-free / data-driven approaches. The data-driven solution approach can potentially set the stage for the development of more sophisticated algorithms that can be applied to real world problems in which high-fidelity models are typically not available a priori. For the low-level control problem, we developed coverage control algorithms which account for the dynamics of the service demand (microscopic control based on local information). The latter algorithms leverage the solution to the high-level problem to characterize individual actions for the team?s constituents which are compatible with the team?s objectives. We have also created tools that ensure that the agents can operate safely even in a workspace which can be populated by obstacles (cluttered environments). 

This exploratory research (EAGER) project supported in part four graduate students and lead to the publication of several journal articles in flagship journals in the field as well as peer reviewed conference papers which were presented at some of the premier conferences in control theory and engineering. Finally, this research project contributed to undergraduate education by introducing undergraduate students to basic research problems and by helping them become familiar with analytical and algorithmic tools related to key problems of the emerging field of multiagent control systems and their applications.
